general: This law allows the government to spend money on things like schools, hospitals, and the military for the next few years. It also lets the government borrow money from the bank to pay for these things if they don't have enough money in their accounts. This helps the government plan its spending and make sure it has enough money to do all the things it needs to do.

series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The act authorizes the use of resources for the year ending March 31st, 2016, up to £248,938,199,000, with £222,417,912,000 for current purposes and £26,520,287,000 for capital purposes.
* Simplified point 2: The Treasury can issue money out of the Consolidated Fund and apply it for expenditure authorized by parliament, up to £219,606,746,000.
* Simplified point 3: The act also makes adjustments to the Main Estimates Act 2014, increasing the amount of authorized expenditure by £10,564,522,000, and reducing the amount of authorized expenditure by £25,966,065,000.
* Simplified point 4: The act appropriates the amount of resources the use of which for the year ending March 31st, 2014 was authorized by section 4(1) of the Supply and Appropriation (Anticipation and Adjustments) Act 2014, and makes adjustments to the Scheduled Estimates in the Main Estimates Act 2013.

summary:
The Supply and Appropriation (Anticipation and Adjustments) Act 2015 allows the government to spend money for the years ending March 31st, 2014, March 31st, 2015, and March 31st, 2016. This law gives permission for the government to use up to £248,938,199,000 for these three years, with £222,417,912,000 for things like salaries and other day-to-day costs, and £26,520,287,000 for big projects like building new roads or schools.
The government can take money from the Consolidated Fund to pay for things that have been approved by Parliament, up to £219,606,746,000. This means that the government has permission to spend this amount of money over the next three years.
This law also makes some changes to the amounts of money that were already approved for spending in previous laws. It increases the amount of money available for spending by £10,564,522,000, and reduces the amount of money available for spending by £25,966,065,000.
In short, this law lets the government spend money for the next three years, and sets aside specific amounts of money for different things like salaries and big projects.
single:
* Authorizes the use of resources for the years ending with 31 March 2014, 31 March 2015, and 31 March 2016.
* Authorizes the issue of sums out of the Consolidated Fund for the years ending with 31 March 2015 and 31 March 2016.
* Appropriates the supply authorized by this Act for the years ending with 31 March 2014 and 31 March 2015.
* Provides for supplementary provision for 2014-15, including a reduction of £25,966,065,000 in the amount of resources authorized for use for the year ending with 31 March 2015.
* Provides for excesses for 2013-14, including an increase of £564,706,000 in the amount of resources authorized for use for the year ending with 31 March 2014.
* Appropriates the amount of money the issue of which out of the Consolidated Fund is authorized by section 2(3).
* Specifies the amounts by which adjustments are to be treated as made to the amounts specified in the Scheduled Estimates in the Main Estimates Act 2014 and to the amounts treated as so specified.
* Provides for the adjustments to be treated as having had effect from the beginning of 1 April 2013 and 1 April 2014.
* Gives the Act the short title of the Supply and Appropriation (Anticipation and Adjustments) Act 2015.
